SECTION 1
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
PLANT INFORMATION
Facility Name: Miramar Water Treatment Plant
San Diego, CA 92131
Parent Company: City of San Diego, Water Department
RMP Facility ID: 100000044524
Submission Receipt Date: January 2006
POLICY
The City of San Diego Water Department has and continues to design facilities, operate
and maintain equipment, and commit the personnel and resources to meet or exceed
industry standards and regulatory requirements. The City has developed and
implemented the Process Safety Management/Risk Management Prevention Program
which provides a systematic approach to employee involvement, safety awareness,
emergency response, risk management, and program assessment related to chlorine
facilities at the plant.
PLANT DESCRIPTION
The Miramar Water Treatment Plant (WTP) was originality built in the early 1960's and
treats water for the northern portion of the City of San Diego and for sale to other
agencies. The Miramar Water Treatment Plant has a maximum water treatment capacity
of 140 million gallons per day (MGD), with a future capital improvement project goal of
expanding capacity to 215 MGD. The Miramar Water Treatment Plant is located
adjacent to the south shore of Lake Miramar Reservoir in a predominantly residential
area in the northern portion of the City of San Diego. The surrounding terrain is relatively
hilly. Currently, there is significant amount of existing residential development to the
south, west, and east of the facility, and there is a significant amount of existing
commercial development to the west of the facility. The Miramar WTP currently uses
chlorine to disinfect water from Miramar Reservoir and the California Aqueduct, making
it suitable for use in the City of San Diego's drinking water distribution system and for
sale to other agencies. The chlorine is received in one-ton pressurized liquid containers
at the secured Chlorine Storage Room of the Chlorine Building. The Chlorine Storage
room is equipped to store a maximum

inventory of 22 containers for a total of
approximately 44,000 lbs. of chlorine. Upgrades have been continually made in order to
improve the safety of the chlorine process equipment. The most recent upgrades were
implemented in 2005 (see Table 3-1 in Section 3).
COMMITMENT
1
The Miramar Water Treatment Plant has a well trained and committed operations and
maintenance staff with a record of over 40 years of using chlorine safely. To support the
efforts of continued safe handling and use of chlorine at the Miramar Water Treatment
Plant, senior management has committed to the development of a comprehensive Process
Safety Management Program under the guidelines of State and Federal mandates which
has involved complete engineering reviews of the chlorine storage and feed system and
design certification.
PROGRAM COMPLIANCE
The Risk Management Prevention and Process Safety Management Programs have been
developed and implemented. The Risk Management Prevention Program is in fulfillment
of the requirements of 40 CFR PART 68 within Section 112(r)(7) of the Clean Air Act
and the California Accidental Release Prevention Program regulations(Title 19, Chapter
4.5 of the California Code of Regulations). The Process Safety Management Program is
in fulfillment of the Occupational Health and Safety Administrations (OSHA) 1910.119,
as well as Cal/OSHAs California Code of Regulations, Title 8, Section 5189, Process
Safety Management of Acutely Hazardous Materials.
As with the use of any hazardous chemicals, the use of chlorine in this treatment process
poses the potential for an accidental release that could have offsite consequences. It is for
this reason that several years ago, under the provisions of the Risk Management Program
Rule (40 CFR PART 68), an assessment of potential offsite consequences of accidental
release scenarios of chlorine to the surrounding environment was conducted at the
Miramar Water Treatment Plant. Under the provisions of the rule, the treatment process
at t

he Miramar Water Treatment Plant is considered a "Program 3" process, and as such
an analysis was conducted of (1) a "worst-case" release scenario and (2) one or more
alternative release scenarios. Incorporated into the Risk Management Plan (RMP) was
the analysis of potential offsite consequences of an accidental chlorine release. This
analysis produces information related to the residential population and public and
environmental receptors which may be affected in the event of a accidental chlorine
release.
SAFETY ELEMENTS
Safety elements can be defined as either administrative or engineering controls.
Administrative elements include; 1) procedural requirements, 2) training, 3) operator
certification, and 4) the City?s policy and commitment of resources. Engineering
elements include physical modifications or facilities to 1) detect, 2) contain, 3) treat, 4)
warn, and/or 5) eliminate a potential incident. The following engineering upgrades were
made to enhance the management and mitigation of an accidental chlorine release (see
Table 3-1 in Section 3 for dates of implementation/review):
1) Chlorine leak detection sensors were installed in the chlorine container storage
building and feed system. These sensors activate alarms within the plant when low levels
of chlorine are detected within the Chlorine Storage Building.
2
2) A computerized process control program allows the Duty Plant Operator to see
immediately from the Operations Control Room what part of the chlorine feed system is
alarming, (and at what chlorine concentration) without leaving the control room.
3) An automatic chlorine shut-off system was installed to minimize a chlorine release by
enabling the operator to stop the chlorine feed at the cylinder in the event of a release.
4) An automatic switchover system was installed, which allows for the automated
switchover from the two on-line containers to the two standby containers
The following administrative safety controls have been implemented:
1) Several

safe-work-practices for the operations and maintenance sections have been
developed in conjunction with other safety programs to insure employees work and
respond to incidents safely. The Miramar Water Treatment Plant, in conjunction with the
Water Department Emergency Management Coordinator, have developed and tested a
Chlorine Emergency Response Plan. The Chlorine Emergency Response Plan was
developed to support the Water Plant staff in the event of a chlorine release in which
additional resources are required to mitigate the situation. The San Diego Fire
Department?s Hazardous Materials Incident Response Team (HIRT) is dedicated to
respond to the plant in the event of an incident which exceeds the response capabilities of
the plant staff. The Miramar Water Treatment Plant maintains a Business Plan that
identifies evacuation points on the site and provides additional emergency information
about chlorine and additional contacts if needed. All personnel assigned to this site are
trained and certified on the provisions of this Business Plan.
ACCIDENT HISTORY
In the last five years, one reportable incident related to a chlorine release has occurred at
the Miramar Water Treatment Plant. This incident, which occurred in 2002, resulted in no
offsite consequences, and the worker involved suffered only minor injuries. The City
maintains comprehensive Incident Investigation and Emergency Response Programs in
the event of an incident. Ongoing Emergency Response training and operator and staff
certification assure that plant personnel maintain familiarity with safety and emergency
procedures and available emergency response resources.
COMPLIANCE AUDIT
A Process Safety Management (PSM) compliance audit was conducted by an outside
consultant in 2005 in accordance with applicable Cal-OSHA regulations, specifically
Paragraph (0), 8 CCR, ? 5189 of Cal-OSHA. The purpose of the audit was to evaluate the
adequacy of the PSM and RMP programs and provide recommendations of
improvement

s as needed. The City of San Diego Water Department Safety Committee
and Emergency Management Coordinator are currently reviewing the audit
documentation.
3
EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
The City of San Diego has trained and certified all plant staff to the level of first
responder. Additional support will be provided by the San Diego Fire Department?s
Hazardous Materials Incident Response Team (HIRT). In the event HIRT is required,
plant staff can mobilize all necessary resources with a single radio or telephone call. In
addition, an automated dialing system has been installed. This system automatically
contacts relevant responders (HIRT and/or plant staff) in the event that a chlorine
concentration threshold is detected by the gas sensors in the Chlorine Room. All relevant
design and operations of chlorine facilities at Miramar WTP have received thorough
review by the Fire Department prior to construction or implementation. Fire Department
staff have worked closely with plant staff to develop a thorough familiarity with the
operation of chlorine facilities in order to facilitate efficient emergency response.
PLANNED CHANGES
The Miramar Water Treatment Plant has received numerous engineering upgrades
throughout the last decade. Facilities planned or currently in construction including:
1. Additional video monitoring of chemical storage and feed facilities.
2. Installation of a `scrubber? system, capable of neutralizing 2000 pounds of
chlorine. The operation of the scrubber may be activated by installed leak
detection equipment or may be initiated manually by staff.
3. Construction of a new chlorine room designed as a containment structure,
eliminating free discharge of chlorine to the atmosphere
The City of San Diego Water Department and the Miramar Plant staff are committed to
providing `state of the art? facilities that produce high quality drinking water while
protecting the environment and the health and safety of plant staff and the public.
